topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack 1.1: Monitor Disk Usage

body.p: The Icinga service, which runs in the undercloud, helps cloud admins monitor the disk usage of Object Storage (Swift) storage node(s).

ul.li:
HPE Helion OpenStack cloud is successfully deployed.
(Starter Object Storage (Swift) nodes are functional by default as they are part of cloud deployment)
The Icinga service is active and running in the undercloud.

section.title: Monitoring Disk Usage of Object Storage (Swift)

ul.li: That the file systems used by the servers are mounted.
The disk usage (by percentage) for the devices in use by Swift (/srv/node). Note that other file systems such as /usr or /var are not monitored.

section.p: Perform the following steps to monitor the usage of Swift disk:

ol.li:
In the undercloud Horizon dashboard, log in to the Icinga Dashboard (http://<Undercloud_IP>/icinga/). The default login credentials are as follows:
Username: icingaadmin
Password: icingaadmin

Click Status on the left panel and click Host Details.
The page navigates to the Host Status Details for all Hosts.

In the Host column, click the icon next to the host IP when the tooltip displays as "View Service Details For This Host" (as shown in the above image). The page navigates to Service Status Details For Host <Swift node IP address > and displays the disk usage of the selected Swift node.

row.entry: Percent disk usage for devices used by Swift (/srv/node)

The percentage used space of one of the disk drives exceeds the user defined threshold(Default set to 85% for HPE Helion OpenStack 1.0). It is important to prevent Swift devices becoming full because it is difficult to recover if this happens. To resolve, add more devices to the rings or ask your users to delete objects.

The available space on one of the disk drives has dropped below the "fallocate_reserve" given in <object-server-configuration>. If no value is given in the object server configuration file, this value defaults to zero. Swift cannot store more data on the drive if the available space drops below this defined limit.
